question_text: Which of the following are sets? Justify your answer. (i) The collection of all the months of a year beginning with the letter J. (ii) The collection of ten most talented writers of India. (iii) A team of eleven best‐cricket batsmen of the world. (iv) The collection of all boys in your class. (v) The collection of all natural numbers less than 100. (vi) A collection of novels written by the writer Munshi Prem Chand. (vii) The collection of all even integers. (viii) The collection of questions in this Chapter. (ix) A collection of most dangerous animals of the world.
correct_answer: A mathematical set must be a well-defined collection in which, for each object, there is a definite criterion to decide membership. In the given list: (i) is a set if all months beginning with J (January, June, July) are clearly defined. (ii) and (iii) are not well-defined because criteria ("ten most talented" or "best") are subjective. (iv) and (v) are sets provided that the class and natural numbers (<100) are clearly specified. (vi) is a set as the novels written by Munshi Prem Chand can be listed. (vii) is a set by virtue of the defining property (even integers). (viii) is a set if the chapter is fixed. (ix) is not well-defined because “most dangerous” is subjective.
explanation: To determine if a collection qualifies as a mathematical set, we check whether there is a clear and objective property that decides whether any given element should be included. Subjective terms such as 'talented', 'best', or 'most dangerous' lack the necessary precision. For collections like months or natural numbers less than 100, the property is clear and objective. Thus, by analyzing each item one by one, the answer classifies which collections meet the well-defined criterion.

question_text: Let A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}. Insert the appropriate symbol (∈ or ∉) in the blank spaces: (i) 5 __ A (ii) 8 __ A (iii) 0 __ A (iv) 4 __ A (v) 2 __ A (vi) 10 __ A
explanation: For a number to belong to the set A = {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, it must be one of the listed elements. Since 5, 4, and 2 are in the set, we write 5 ∈ A, 4 ∈ A, and 2 ∈ A. On the other hand, 8, 0, and 10 are not in the set, so we have 8 ∉ A, 0 ∉ A, and 10 ∉ A.

question_text: Write the following sets in roster form: (i) A = { x : x is an integer and -3 ≤ x < 7 } (ii) B = { x : x is a natural number less than 6 } (iii) C = { x : x is a two-digit natural number such that the sum of its digits is 8 } (iv) D = { x : x is a prime number which is a divisor of 60 } (v) E = The set of all letters in the word TRIGONOMETRY (vi) F = The set of all letters in the word BETTER.
explanation: For (i), list all integers starting at -3 up to but not including 7. For (ii), natural numbers less than 6 are 1 through 5. For (iii), identify two-digit numbers whose digits add up to 8 (e.g., 17: 1+7=8, 26: 2+6=8, etc.). For (iv), list the prime divisors of 60; since 60 factors as 2^2×3×5, the prime divisors are 2, 3, and 5. For (v) and (vi), list the unique letters from the given words, keeping in mind that repetition is omitted in set notation.

correct_answer:
(i) { x : x = 3n, where n ∈ {1,2,3,4} } or equivalently { x : x is a multiple of 3 and 3 ≤ x ≤ 12 }.
(ii) { x : x = 2^n, where n ∈ {1,2,3,4,5} }.
(iii) { x : x = 5^n, where n ∈ {1,2,3,4} }.
(iv) { x : x = 2n, where n ∈ ℕ }.
(v) { x : x = n^2, where n ∈ ℕ and 1 ≤ n ≤ 10 }.
explanation: For each set, recognize the underlying pattern. (i) numbers are 3, 6, 9, 12 which can be written as 3×n where n takes specific values. (ii) and (iii) are geometric sequences with bases 2 and 5, respectively. (iv) represents the even numbers and (v) represents perfect squares from 1^2 up to 10^2.

question_text: List all the elements of the following sets: (i) A = { x : x is an odd natural number } (ii) B = { x : x is an integer, -½ ≤ x ≤ 9/2 } (iii) C = { x : x is an integer, x² ≤ 4 } (iv) D = { x : x is a letter in the word “LOYAL” } (v) E = { x : x is a month of a year not having 31 days } (vi) F = { x : x is a consonant in the English alphabet which precedes k }.
correct_answer:
(i) A is infinite: {1, 3, 5, 7, ...}.
(ii) B = {0, 1, 2, 3, 4} because these are the integers between -0.5 and 4.5.
(iii) C = {-2, -1, 0, 1, 2} since x² ≤ 4 holds for these values.
(iv) D = {L, O, Y, A} (unique letters in 'LOYAL').
(v) E = {February, April, June, September, November} as these months do not have 31 days.
(vi) F = {B, C, D, F, G, H, J} – the English alphabet letters before k, excluding vowels (A, E, I).
explanation: For (i), note that the set of odd natural numbers is unbounded, so we denote it with ellipsis. For (ii), list integers based on the given inequality. For (iii), solve x² ≤ 4, yielding x values from -2 to 2. For (iv), extract unique characters from the word. For (v), knowledge of the calendar is used to identify months without 31 days. For (vi), list the consonants that occur before the letter 'k' in the English alphabet (letters A to J, with vowels removed).

question_text: Match each of the sets on the left in roster form with the corresponding set on the right described in set-builder form: (i) {1, 2, 3, 6} (ii) {2, 3} (iii) {M, A, T, H, E, I, C, S} (iv) {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} with (a) { x : x is a prime number and a divisor of 6 } (b) { x : x is an odd natural number less than 10 } (c) { x : x is a natural number and divisor of 6 } (d) { x : x is a letter of the word MATHEMATICS }.
correct_answer: (i) {1, 2, 3, 6} matches (c) because these are all natural number divisors of 6. (ii) {2, 3} matches (a) since 2 and 3 are both prime numbers and divisors of 6. (iii) {M, A, T, H, E, I, C, S} matches (d) as they are the letters in the word MATHEMATICS (excluding the repeated letter). (iv) {1, 3, 5, 7, 9} matches (b) since these are odd natural numbers less than 10.
explanation: Analyze each set: (i) lists all divisors of 6, regardless of primality, which corresponds to option (c); (ii) only contains the prime divisors of 6, corresponding to (a); (iii) is a letter set from the word MATHEMATICS, matching (d); (iv) is clearly the set of odd natural numbers less than 10, matching (b).
topic: Set Theory – Matching Roster and Set-Builder Forms
